question: Question_01_(a)
statement:
Let \emph{L} be the line which is parallel to the plane

\[\displaystyle{}2x+y-z=5\]

and perpendicular to the line

\[x=3-t\qquad{}y=1-2t\qquad{}z=3t.\]

Find a vector parallel to the line \emph{L}.
sols:
Let the line L be written in vector form as

\[\displaystyle
[a_{0},b_{0},c_{0}] + [a_{1},b_{1},b_{2}]t.\] If L is parallel to the
plane 2x + y - z = 5, then L must be perpendicular to the normal vector
of said plane, n = {[}2,1,-1{]}. i.e. The dot product between n and the
direction of L must be equal to zero:

\[[2,1,-1]\cdot[a_{1},b_{1},c_{1}] = 0.\] Evaluating the dot product
gives:

\[\mathbf{(1)} \quad [2,1,-1]\cdot[a_{1},b_{1},c_{1}] = 2a_{1} + b_{1} - c_{1} = 0\]
Remember that we also need the vector is perpendicular to the
line,$[3 - t, 1 - 2t, 3t] = [3,1,0] + [-1,-2,3]t.$ Hence, the following
equation must also be satisfied:

\[\displaystyle
\mathbf{(2)} \quad [-1,-2,3] \cdot [a_{1},b_{1},c_{1}] = -a_{1} - 2b_{1} + 3c_{1} = 0\]
So we have two equations and three unknowns. This means there are
infinitely many vectors that will satisfy the given conditions. We only
need to find one. Solving (1) for $c_{1}$ gives
$c_{1} = 2a_{1} + b_{1}$. Subbing this into (2) gives

\[\displaystyle
-a_{1} - 2b_{1} + 3(2a_{1} + b_{1}) = 0 \quad \rightarrow \quad b_{1} = -5a_{1}.\]
From this we get that $c_{1} = 2a_{1} - 5a_{1} = -3a_{1}$.

Thus, any vector of the form k{[}1,-5,-3{]} where k is a constant (not
equal to zero) will be parallel to L. For example, the vectors
{[}1,-5,-3{]} and {[}-2,10,6{]} are acceptable solutions.

(Note: Clearly $a_{1} = b_{1} = c_{1} = 0$ is a solution to the above
equations (1), (2), but it is the trivial solution and is perpendicular
to every vector, including the direction of the line L.)
